subdomains.name: Propositional Logic
subdomains.description: The logic of statements connected by AND, OR, NOT, and IF-THEN. The foundation of all formal reasoning.
subdomains.flavor: The Gateway of Reason — where truth and falsehood first learn to dance.

topics.name: Truth Tables & Connectives
topics.description: Systematic enumeration of all possible truth values for compound propositions built from AND, OR, NOT, IF-THEN, and IFF.
topics.flavor: Every possible world, laid out in rows and columns.

topics.name: Logical Equivalence
topics.description: Two statements are logically equivalent when they share the same truth value in every possible scenario. De Morgan's laws and contrapositive reasoning.
topics.flavor: Different words, same truth — the art of saying it another way.

topics.name: Normal Forms (CNF/DNF)
topics.description: Canonical representations of logical formulas as conjunctions of disjunctions (CNF) or disjunctions of conjunctions (DNF).
topics.flavor: Every formula has a skeleton — strip away the flesh and find the bones.

topics.name: Boolean Algebra
topics.description: An algebraic structure over {0, 1} with operations AND, OR, and NOT. The mathematical backbone of digital circuits and logic gates.
topics.flavor: Zeros and ones — the binary heartbeat of every machine ever built.

topics.name: Proof Systems (Natural Deduction)
topics.description: Formal systems for deriving conclusions from premises using introduction and elimination rules for each connective.
topics.flavor: Step by careful step, truth is built from the ground up.

subdomains.name: Predicate Logic
subdomains.description: Extending propositional logic with variables, predicates, and quantifiers to reason about objects and their properties.
subdomains.flavor: The Voice of Universes — where logic learns to speak about everything and anything.

topics.name: Quantifiers
topics.description: The universal quantifier (for all) and existential quantifier (there exists), enabling statements about collections of objects.
topics.flavor: For all stars in the sky, there exists one that shines just for you.

topics.name: First-Order Logic
topics.description: A formal language with predicates, functions, constants, and quantifiers over individuals. The standard framework for mathematical reasoning.
topics.flavor: The common tongue of mathematics — precise enough to leave no room for ambiguity.

topics.name: Completeness Theorem
topics.description: Godel's completeness theorem: every logically valid first-order sentence is provable. Semantics and syntax perfectly align.
topics.flavor: Everything true can be proven — a rare and beautiful harmony.

topics.name: Compactness Theorem
topics.description: A set of first-order sentences has a model if and only if every finite subset has a model. A bridge between the finite and the infinite.
topics.flavor: Infinity bows to the finite — if every piece fits, the whole must too.

topics.name: Model Theory Basics
topics.description: The study of mathematical structures through the lens of formal languages. Interpretations, structures, and the relationship between syntax and semantics.
topics.flavor: Words shape worlds — and every sentence carves out the universes that obey it.

subdomains.name: Set Theory
subdomains.description: The study of collections of objects and the axioms that govern them. The bedrock upon which all of modern mathematics is constructed.
subdomains.flavor: The Foundations — the soil from which every mathematical structure grows.

topics.name: Naive Set Theory (ZFC Axioms)
topics.description: Sets as collections of objects, governed by the Zermelo-Fraenkel axioms with Choice. Union, intersection, power set, and the avoidance of paradoxes.
topics.flavor: Gather things together — but carefully, lest the universe collapse into paradox.

topics.name: Relations & Functions
topics.description: Binary relations, equivalence relations, partial orders, and functions as special relations. The structural glue of mathematics.
topics.flavor: How things connect — the invisible threads binding every mathematical object.

topics.name: Cardinality & Countability
topics.description: Comparing the sizes of infinite sets. Cantor's diagonal argument, countable vs uncountable, and the continuum hypothesis.
topics.flavor: Some infinities are bigger than others — Cantor dared to count the uncountable.

topics.name: Ordinals & Cardinals
topics.description: Ordinal numbers extend counting beyond the finite. Cardinal numbers measure set sizes. Transfinite induction and arithmetic.
topics.flavor: Numbers that reach past infinity, climbing an endless staircase of alephs.

topics.name: Axiom of Choice
topics.description: The controversial axiom stating that a choice function exists for every collection of non-empty sets. Equivalent to Zorn's lemma and the well-ordering theorem.
topics.flavor: You can always choose — even when the choices are infinite and invisible.

subdomains.name: Computability
subdomains.description: The mathematical study of what can and cannot be computed. Turing machines, decidability, and the inherent limits of algorithms.
subdomains.flavor: The Edge of the Knowable — where mathematics meets the limits of mechanical thought.

topics.name: Turing Machines
topics.description: An abstract model of computation with a tape, head, and finite set of states. The formal definition of what it means to compute.
topics.flavor: A strip of tape, a reading head, and a handful of rules — enough to compute anything computable.

topics.name: Decidability
topics.description: A problem is decidable if a Turing machine can always halt with the correct yes/no answer. Separating the solvable from the unsolvable.
topics.flavor: Some questions have no algorithm — no matter how clever you are.

topics.name: Halting Problem
topics.description: The undecidable problem of determining whether a given Turing machine halts on a given input. Proven by diagonalization.
topics.flavor: Will it stop? The question no machine can answer about itself.

topics.name: Recursive Functions
topics.description: The class of functions computable by Turing machines. Primitive recursive and mu-recursive functions as an alternative formalization of computability.
topics.flavor: Functions that call themselves into existence, spiraling down to an answer.

topics.name: Godel's Incompleteness
topics.description: Any consistent formal system strong enough to express arithmetic contains true statements it cannot prove. The inherent limitations of formal reasoning.
topics.flavor: Truth outruns proof — there will always be stars beyond the reach of any telescope.
